In game 1, I got a first blood kill with my support. After that he decided to not come to bot lane anymore and he was constantly at mid lane all game and as a result I was flaming him. But can you really blame me in this situation when someone is purposely going out of their way to ruin your gaming experience? In game 2, I don't see how it was being toxic because it was just banter between me and my support. 

I've been playing this game since season 3 and I've never been banned until now season 9. Three or four months ago I was banned for 2 weeks, that was my first offence ever since playing this game. After then I had only one bad day with two bad games, the first game resulted me to tilt into the game 2. 

After the 2-week suspension I was reformed for 3-4 months and I never went out of my way of putting down other players with toxicity. Just one bad day of two games and I'm being judged in all my 7 years of playing this game. I feel completely shattered now knowing that I will probably never get my account back after spending so much time and money into this game. I've sent numerous tickets to RIot games and they've all replied with the exact same answer with NO removal of the punishment etc. However I had one response that told me to post here on the boards for review.

Riot games please give me one more chance to reform, I know now its not right to be abusive towards players even though they are abusive, griefing or purposely ruining the gaming experience for you. It's sad to say but I think Riot games just don't care deeply for their players anymore..Praying for one rioter to do a good samaritan here please.

So the short answer to your question is no, this punishment will not be revoked. What I can do is offer you some more context, though if you've submitted tickets then some or most you will have probably already received. I'll try to boil it down to your key concerns to keep it concise.
___
**.1. Why were you punished in this manner?**

Typically punishment follows four tiers: 

* 10 game chat restriction
* 25 game chat restriction
* 14-day ban
* Permanent ban

However, it is possible to skip tiers depending on the severity and type of behaviour. Gameplay offences for example (intent feeding, griefing, etc) skip the two chat restriction tiers since a chat restriction doesn't make much sense in that case. The other thing that will skip those chat restrictions is what is classed by Riot as "no-tolerance language". This includes discriminatory language/hate speech (sexism, racism, etc) and suicide encouragement ("kys", etc).

Given that you said you received your first punishment recently, and in the form of a 14-day ban, I imagine one of those applies to you. If not, some more info from your part would be appreciated to give the full picture.


___
**.2. Why does my clean 7-year history not matter?**

In short, it does. I would say that what damned you here was that initial 14-day. To receive that 14-day as your first punishment, there must have been some pretty serious behaviour going on there (as mentioned above).

Essentially, after that 14-day your account is no longer an old, previously clean account, but is instead now an account with a recent history of *serious* toxicity. 

In saying that, constantly calling people things like "spastic" and "dogshit" would have probably run you afoul of the system regardless of your clean history, but without that initial escalation it probably would have been a chat restriction. 

To put it in perspective, if I go my whole life without stealing anything, I might get let off easy for stealing a candy bar (still illegal though), but not so much for stealing a car. While there are rewards for being an upstanding citizen, not stealing things is the expectation not the accomplishment.
___
**.3. But they started it.**

It doesn't matter. Frustration is expected in those scenarios, but abuse is not. If nothing else, anything you say at that point is going to make things worse, and not just for you and the person being an ass, but also for the other *innocent* players in your games.

Ultimately, you are held responsible for your behaviour, just as they are responsible for their own. If you reported them, then they will be held accountable in the same manner.
___
**.4. Can I have one more chance?**

Unfortunately no. The 14-day ban was your chance and your warning. Given that you were sitting on that 14-day received tier, that meant your next punishment was going to be a permanent suspension. This should have been made clear in the reform card for your 14-day. It is possible to drop tiers, but it takes a lot of time and at least neutral gameplay to do so.

The punishment tiers are chosen very specifically, with a lot of data to back them up. The short version is, after that 14-day tier, reform rates drop to almost nil. Giving players that extra chance, results in almost 100% relapse rate, which hurts *far* more innocent players that have to be in those games than it does the odd player who would actually reform.

> you can't just assume every player is going to be toxic in gameplay ways

It's not an assumption, it's a statistic. Before the IFS existed, permanent chat restrictions did (to be more specific, infinitely stacking chat restrictions). Among those that offended enough to get more than 1-2 chat restrictions stacked on their account, the stacked chat restrictions had basically 0 impact on toxicity/negativity. Why would they continue to use a system that does nothing?

>As for me I won't

Won't you though? Don't take this the wrong way, I'm simply trying to put it into perspective for you. Consider that from the outside, you are a player that ran afoul of the system and received a 14-day ban, were *explicitly* warned that any further violations would result in loss of your account, and despite having a purely selfish reason not to offend again you did so. 

If you were permanently chat restricted, there would be no personal incentive for you to improve your behaviour, because there is no worse in that scenario. If you didn't control your behaviour to save your account, why would you control it just to prevent another stack of chat restrictions?

> permanently banning which completely disregards that persons hard spent time and money on the game

If I refrain from murder for 20 years of my life and then murder someone at 21, I don't get a free pass because of my 20 years of not murdering people. Not murdering people is the expectation, not an accomplishment.

> literally zero loyalty or respect to their players

Giving every perma-banned player 1 more shot to reform, with the knowledge that 99+% of those players are going to go right back to being toxic within a few games, is disrespecting every single other player that those banned players will play with in that time, every single player that has never been punished, and especially every single player that got punished and made a real effort to reform and get their account back into good standing. Riot simply cannot choose that <1% of players over the 99%. It doesn't make sense to make that choice.

>the tribunal system was much better at locating what is toxic and whats not

It really wasn't. The tribunal system universally punished more harshly and more often than the IFS does, for even the most minor of infractions. It required so much oversight from Riot that almost every case required manual review, which entirely defeated the purpose.

>Never have I seen a case of their players complaining on how their system works

Any online game (see OW, WoW, DOTA, HotS, CoD, CS, etc, etc) has people complaining that they get punished for 'nothing', when more often than not they are forgetting that they are playing an *M/13+ rated* game and that going off at someone for making a mistake isn't an appropriate way to behave, in-game or otherwise.

By the way you're ignoring the fact Riot games has zero loyalty to their players, why would they have in their terms and conditions that our accounts is their property, just pure greed. It's not about the effort it's about risk vs reward. Literally any banned player could say "I promise I won't do it again, I just need one more chance". The statistics say that 99~% of those players when given that chance, would go right back to hurting innocent players. 

If you give that chance, you have a tiny percentage of any already tiny percentage of players benefitting, but you also have a much larger number of players hurt by those that haven't benefitted. Or, you have the current system where that tiny percentage of a tiny percentage suffers, but the majority doesn't. You can't please everyone, and no system is perfect.

The murder thing was an analogy, same as the stealing thing. You don't expect congratulations for following the law, but you do expect punishment for breaking it. The same applies here. You knew what the rules were, if only because you brushed with the system in the past and were explicitly warned of the consequences. 

A murderer who was jailed, got out, and then murdered another person 3-4 months later probably *would* be jailed for life, since they've proved that a timed sentence isn't a deterrent and they didn't learn any sort of lesson like "murdering people is bad" from the experience.

If you play literally any online game, you don't own those accounts. You rent them. This is not a Riot thing, it is a business thing. It exists to protect them and to protect us.

I never at any point said that tribunal was run by a bot. I said it universally punished more harshly, more often, and less accurate than the current system (which is a computer learning system) does.

I *have* played those other games. While I can't profess to be as intimate with the details of their punishment systems, I do know that *any* system has its flaws, and there will always be people who disagree with how things are moderated. Every person is unique and it is literally impossible to make every single person happy.

Any large group of people, be it a church group or a multi-billion dollar gaming company have to appease their majority. Riot isn't going to cater to the few hundred people who would benefit from that extra chance over the thousands that would be hurt by it. It does not make any sort of sense to do so.
